review_title: NO BREAKS, WORKING EVERY WEEKEND, NO WEEKEND ROTATION, NO RECOGNITION.
pros: Hilton honors discount, but honestly Marriott's is better. I can never find cheap rooms or even hilton hotels where I wanna vacation. Marriott hotels are no issue and with marriott you can book rooms for as low as 39$, hilton its like always hit or miss.
cons: You will enjoy this type of job if you love being stuck behind a desk all day, dealing with the world of karens and groups (soccer group bookings), not being able to leave behind the desk or sit down on your shift unless you are going for a bathroom break or lunch break, you will at least have to wait 15 mins after you ask for a bathroom break and remind your managers constantly that you need to take your lunch. Some days you wont even get a lunch and will have to run off to the back to try and eat a snack on your 8hr work day. There will also be times when you are left alone at the front desk around 6ish pm after all the managers have gone home and have to deal with angry guests, random large group bookings that come in and you were given no notice of. In short, you will hate it here like everyone I have met has and either leave within 3 months or stick it out, be a great employee but also be nitpicked at by your supervisor, have no lunch breaks, no 15 or even 10 min breaks, and have to sneak away to use the restroom and remind managers constantly of getting your benefit to getting a great review.

review_title: Hilton is the most amazing place to work!
pros: The company culture is one like no other. Everyone is treated with respect and dignity and everyone has a voice. Education and skills strengthening and growth is encouraged. Hilton even provides their own free university as well as access to external learning, including eCornell. Growing your own career is even part of your yearly goals and worked through with your leadership. They also have a lot of fun activities to keep morale up and work-life balance is well maintained.
cons: The only con is the competition on each job at Hilton. With team members never wanting to leave and so many wanting to come in, when new positions open up it's very hard to get eyes on yourself because so many are applying.

job_title: Marcomms Senior Manager in McLean, VA
pros:
At face value, my time at Hilton was full of great opportunities to travel and build up my resume. It would be remiss of me to not be grateful for those opportunities and the few lifelong friends I made in the process.
 That being said, this all came at the cost of a very high stress environment ( I know multiple people who would cry in huddle rooms thanks to the abrasive personalities they dealt with and the massive work load put upon them), passive and apathetic (or for some, down right MEAN) leadership and a lack of acknowledgement for hard work unless you kissed up to the right people.
cons:
Dependent on team, but for most marcomms team members, hours are often long and tedious with lots of travel (which can be fun, depends what phase of life you are in). In many cases Director levels and above don't do much (e.g: leave the office by 4pm to go home or to happy hour) but expect Senior Managers and below to stay late, always be available and single handedly manage agency teams. The environment was highly political and full of favoritism. 
The reward was high profile campaigns and a sense of pride to work for "cool" company -- pre covid, fancy team dinners/happy hours, snacks and swag were all the norm.

Also, they severely underpay for marcomms rolles in the DC area. The travel perks and "glamour" keep people interested in working there.

pros: I've been with Hilton now almost 4 years and I can say without a doubt I have never had a team or managers that care so much about me and my family life outside of work. I have never had an issue with needing to take time off or work remote out of the blue. The trust is there and you can feel it. They are huge on self-initiative and LOVE innovative ideas. You got something to share? Bring it. It doesn't always mean they will use it but I have never felt belittled or ridiculed for coming up with another solution of how to complete a task.
cons: It's really hard to get promoted. Employees have been here 10+ years so when an opportunity rises, of course the more tenured ones are going to get it! Catch 20-20, right? That goes to show you how well they treat everyone -- no one ever wants to leave!

cons:
Outsourcing Strategy and Lack of Strategic Vision on Non-Hospitality Departments

Every year the company brags that it won the "Best Place to Work" type award. How can you have the best place to work when you do not have employees? Operational functions such as Accounting and IT are outsourced. 
Planning departmental strategies and road maps are biased. If you ask your outsourcing partner on their strategic recommendations, they are probably going to favor a solution that includes them.
